title: 115_s2080
content: The Act titled "End Banking for Human Traffickers Act of 2017" aims to coordinate human trafficking issues through the Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence. The Act "End Banking for Human Traffickers Act of 2017" amends Section 312(a)(4) of title 31, United States Code to combat illicit financing related to human trafficking. It also requires interagency coordination efforts to combat the illicit financing of human trafficking. The Act "End Banking for Human Traffickers Act of 2017" amends Section 312(a)(4) of title 31, United States Code to combat illicit financing related to human trafficking through coordination with Treasury, other Federal agencies, State and local law enforcement agencies, and foreign governments. The Act "End Banking for Human Traffickers Act of 2017" aims to strengthen the role of anti-money laundering and other financial tools in combating human trafficking. The Interagency Task Force is required to submit an analysis of anti-money laundering efforts related to human trafficking to various committees and agencies within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The Interagency Task Force must provide recommendations to strengthen efforts against money laundering related to human trafficking, including best practices from successful programs at financial institutions and stakeholder feedback on policy proposals. The Interagency Task Force must provide recommendations to strengthen efforts against money laundering related to human trafficking, including changes to internal policies, training programs at financial institutions, and information sharing among financial institutions and law enforcement agencies. Additionally, there is an additional reporting requirement under the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000. The bill has been amended to include the Committee on Financial Services and the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs in certain sections. It also adds a new provision regarding the United States' efforts to combat money laundering related to human trafficking. The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council, in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury, private sector, and law enforcement agencies, will review and enhance procedures to improve surveillance capabilities for detecting human trafficking-related financial transactions. This includes training and examination procedures, referral of potential human trafficking cases to law enforcement, and assessing the sufficiency of requirements for financial institutions to detect money laundering related to human trafficking.
